pros: People in the community were nice. The physical plant which is outsourced is by far the best run entity on the campus.
cons:
No retirement. They are in extremely poor financial shape and have no leadership. The integrity of the institution is a big question mark.
School had a very tenuous relationship with the community and a poor reputation statewide in both academic achievement and student safety. The value unfortunately of their degree has diminished with every incoming class they recruit as the admissions standards drop due to their desperation to attract tuition dollars from out of state. In state recruiting has become increasingly difficult due to the rise of crime on campus and the administrations apparent inability to handle it and in some cases turn a blind eye to it.

review_title: Charming campus but the most dysfunctional institution ever
pros: There are a lot of nice people working on campus, particularly many of the faculty. The campus is small and cozy, a charming setting in a small town in the Appalachian mountains.  It was especially beautiful in the fall (changing leaves) and spring (blooming Redbud trees). I miss the camaraderie with colleagues from other departments and the get-togethers and social events, but that's about it. There were some surprisingly good people working there and I have not experienced such close-knit and supportive social groups elsewhere.
cons:
This was the most dysfunctional place I've ever worked. The place was a revolving door - the highest turnover rates I've ever heard of for higher education.  I think yearly turnover must rival fast food jobs. Faculty usually like to plan their syllabus and course schedules ahead of time, but it was impossible here. We often did not know final teaching schedule until weeks into the semester. On occasion courses were cancelled due to low enrollment up to 3 weeks into the semester, or courses were switched weeks into the semester (sometimes due to the need to take over a course when adjunct or fulltime faculty quit right before the semester started, or even during the first week or two of the semester).  Due to lack of fulltime faculty, teaching loads were often high (it was not unusual for some faculty to be teaching 7, even 8 courses in a semester) and there was often a reliance on many part time adjunct instructors teaching courses.  If teaching 8 courses and doing it well sounds impossible, you'd be correct.  Often these adjuncts were not vetted well, as departments were desperate to cover courses.  Some departments only had 3 or 4 fulltime faculty but up to 20 or more adjuncts. Sometimes faculty were pressured into teaching low enrollment courses for very little or no money - as little as a few hundred dollars for a semester-long seminar course with several students.  Some faculty reported being threatened with negative performance evaluations if they did not agree to teach an extra course for free. There were a myriad of other problems as well.  Students definitely "ruled the roost" here, and faculty were absolutely not allowed to set standards without administration intervening to appease students.  Some graduate programs were awfully close to being a degree mill, with students taking online courses that were not graded very rigorously if at all.  Many employees were alumni of the college and thus probably did not realize that other institutions just do not operate this way. These problems did tend to have the result of making faculty band together and form a kind of support group. 

Besides all of that, salaries were quite low; some of the very lowest faculty salaries in the entire country if not the very lowest at one time.

review_title: Communication was poor and loyal employees were not valued.
job_title: Assistant Professor, Tenure Track in Barbourville, KY
pros: Small, beautiful campus. Met some nice people on the faculty, and students were good to work with for the most part.
cons: Sports and grounds were placed above academics and faculty salaries.  Communication was horrid.  Did not follow own policies:  Faculty to be downsized were to be informed before Jan 1st.  There were a great number downsized due to lack of finances and none were informed until AFTER Spring Break.

review_title: Toxic work environment, high turnover rate.
job_title: Business Office Assistant in Barbourville, KY
pros: No pros whatsoever,  this place is horrible.
cons: No training for business office assistant. Co worker in the business office has ego issues, jealously runs rampant in business office. If co worker decides she no longer wants the assistant, they terminate them for no other reason than Kentucky is an at will state. These actions have the full support of human resources and the president.

pros: Close knit working community. A lot of potential for growth, as a professional. Don't be afraid to do that little extra to prove that you believe in the mission.
cons: Segmentation has divided some offices from the core mission. Departments can at times fail to share with other areas. This creates a stale environment for the exchange of ideas.
